Package edu.missouri.geom

Class Polygon

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mmkrusniak.geom.Polygon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    public class Polygon
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    A two-dimensional n-gon. It's useful in coverage planning algorithms and area decomposition. Like all geometry components, it is immutable; once a Polygon is created, it cannot be changed, nor can the Points that compose it be modified (as they are also immutable). The polygon is internally represented as an array of points, but it is recommended to use toAngles or toLines as applicable - the indexing remains the same. The coordinate system is y-down, x-right, as reflected in the methods here.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Polygon

        public Polygon​(Point... points)
        Intialize a Polygon from an array of points. The array cannot be null; nor can any point be null.
        Parameters:
        points - A non-null array of Points.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the array or any Point in it is null.

      • Polygon

        public Polygon​(java.util.List<Point> points)
        Initialize a Polygon from a list of points.
        Parameters:
        points - A non-null list of Points.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the array or any Point in it is null.

      • Polygon

        public Polygon​(int n,
               double rad,
               double var)
        Initialize a random simple n-gon. Each corner is generated to be rad units away from a center point, with an additional varying of up to plus var. The leftmost point will sit at x=0 and the topmost point will sit at y=0. The polygon may have small concavities. Not all possible polygons can be generated in this way. Due to a bug some generated polygons are improper.
        Parameters:
        n - Number of points in the generated polygon.
        rad - Minimum distance from each point to a center point. It's analogous to the radius of a circle; when var=0, all points of the polygon lie on a circle of radius rad.
        var - Amount of variance allowed from rad for each vertex. Higher values create spikier polygons.

      • Polygon

        public Polygon​(int n)
        Shortcut for Polygon(n, 100, 300), which generates reasonable polygons for testing.
        Parameters:
        n - Number of points in the generated polygon.

    • Method Detail

      • numSides

        public int numSides()
        Returns the number of sides in the polygon. Note that when an edge contains colinear points, each segment is counted separately.
        Returns:
        The number of sides in the polygon.

      • toPoints

        public Point[] toPoints()
        Returns an array of the points which define this Polygon.
        Returns:
        The points which define this Polygon.

      • toLines

        public Line[] toLines()
        Returns an array of Lines which represent the sides of this polygon. They are in order, such that the line indexed at i and the line indexed at i+1 share a point.
        Returns:
        The lines which define the sides of this Polygon.

      • toAngles

        public Angle[] toAngles()
        Returns an array of Angles which represent the vertices of this polygon. They are in order, such that the angle indexed at i and the angle indexed at i+1 share a line segment. The angles are indexed such that the vertex of the first angle is the first vertex of the polygon.
        Returns:
        The angles which define the vertices of this Polygon.

      • getConvexHull

        public Polygon getConvexHull()
        Gives the convex hull of this Polygon. The convex outline is the result when all concavities of a polygon have been filled. It's a bit like if you stretched a rubber band around the polygon; the shape of the rubber band is the hull.
        Returns:
        The convex hull of this polygon.

      • related

        public Point[] related​(Point p)
        Given a vertex in the polygon, returns the two vertices in the polygon which are adjacent to it. If the given point is not a vertex of the polygon, returns null.
        Parameters:
        p - A point which is a vertex of the polygon.
        Returns:
        An array of two points which are connected to p in the polygon.

      • addPoint

        public Polygon addPoint​(Point point,
                        int v)
        Returns a polygon identical to this one, but with an additional point inserted before the point which currently occupies index v. The original polygon will not be changed.
        Parameters:
        point - A vertex to add to the polygon.
        v - Index before which to add the point (which will become the index of that point).
        Returns:
        A polygon with that vertex added.

      • removePoint

        public Polygon removePoint​(int v)
        Returns a polygon identical to this one, but with the vertex at index v removed. The original polygon will not be changed.
        Parameters:
        v - Index of the vertex to be removed.
        Returns:
        A polygon with that vertex removed.

        Returns:
        The left point of the base of the polygon.

        Returns:
        The right point of the base of the polygon.

      • split

        public Polygon[] split​(int v1,
                       int v2)
        Returns two Polygons which are the result of dividing this one over the line defined by the vertices indexed v1 and v2. The resulting two Polygons will geometrically share an edge (though programmatically, they are totally independent objects).
        Parameters:
        v1 - The first vertex to split by.
        v2 - The second vertex to split by.
        Returns:
        Two Polygons created by splitting this one over v1 and v2.

      • intersections

        public Point[] intersections​(Line l)
        Gives all intersections of a line with this polygon. (If the line is colinear with a line in the polygon, only one (or zero) points are given.)
        Parameters:
        l - A line.
        Returns:
        An array of Point intersections with that line.

      • intersection

        public Point intersection​(Line l)
        Gives the first intersection of a line with the polygon (that is, the intersection closest to l.a(). Best used with rays.
        Parameters:
        l - A line.
        Returns:
        The first intersection of that line with the polygon.

      • rotate

        public Polygon rotate​(double theta)
        Give a polygon which is the result of rotating this one.
        Parameters:
        theta - The amount to rotate the polygon, in radians.
        Returns:
        A rotated polygon.

      • indexOf

        public int indexOf​(Point p)
        Gives the index of a point as a vertex in the polygon, or, if it is not a vertex, the index of the side which the point is closest to.
        Parameters:
        p - A point.
        Returns:
        The index of p in the polygon, either as a vertex or as the side it is closest to.

      • isConcave

        public boolean isConcave()
        Gives whether this Polygon is concave. Many algorithms behave differently with concave polygons than with convex ones.
        Returns:
        Whether this polygon is concave.

      • toAWTPolygon

        public java.awt.Polygon toAWTPolygon()
        Gives this Polygon as a Java AWT polygon, for graphics purposes.
        Returns:
        This polygon as a Java AWT polygon.

      • encloses

        public boolean encloses​(Point p)
        Indicates whether a point lies within this Polygon. A point lying within a concavity is not within the polygon (though it lies within its convex hull).
        Parameters:
        p - A point.
        Returns:
        Whether that point lies within this Polygon.

      • getCartesianBounds

        public java.awt.Rectangle getCartesianBounds()
        Gives the bounds of the polygon as an AWT rectangle. Since a polygon can conceivably be oriented in any way (the choice of cartesian bounds is arbitrary), consider using getPolygonalWidth() or getPolygonalHeight().
        Returns:
        An AWT rectangle which encloses the polygon.

      • render

        public void render​(java.awt.Graphics g)
        Render this polygon on an AWT graphics canvas. Very useful for debugging; consider modifying it to show polygon traits which are relevant you.
        Parameters:
        g - An AWT graphics instance on which to render.

      • distance

        public double distance​(Point p)
        Gives the minimum distance from a point to any point on the polygon (either a vertex or a point lying on a side of the polygon).
        Parameters:
        p - A point.
        Returns:
        The distance from this polygon to the point.

      • getPolygonalWidth

        public double getPolygonalWidth()
        Gives the width of the polygon. Note that this is not the x-width of this polygon as drawn on a screen (the Cartesian width)! Rather, it is the Cartesian width when the polygon is lying on its base. In other words, it is the difference in X spanned by the polygon when it is oriented to be vertically as short as possible. It also happens to be the longer dimension of the smallest square which encompasses the polygon.
        Returns:
        The polygonal width of this polygon.

      • getPolygonalHeight

        public double getPolygonalHeight()
        Gives the height of the polygon. As with getPolygonalWidth(), this is not the y-height of this polygon as drawn on a screen (the Cartesian height)! It is the height of the polygon when oriented to be as vertically short as possible. It also happens to be the shorter dimension of the smallest square which encompasses the polygon.
        Returns:
        The polygonal height of this polygon.

      • getCartesianHeight

        public double getCartesianHeight()
        Gives the Cartesian height of the polygon - the difference between its greatest and lowest vertex Y-coordinates.
        Returns:
        The Cartesian height of the polygon.

      • getCartesianWidth

        public double getCartesianWidth()
        Gives the Cartesian width of the polygon - the difference between its greatest and lowest vertex X-coordinates.
        Returns:
        The Cartesian width of the polygon.

        Returns:
        The perimeter of the polygon.

      • area

        public double area()
        Calculates the area of the polygon. Only supports convex polygons.
        Returns:
        The area of the polygon.

      • reimannArea

        public double reimannArea​(double granularity)
        Gives the area of the polygon as calculated by Reimann sum with a given granularity (horizontally). Useful for calculations about traversing the area with a tool of fixed length. Only supports convex polygons.
        Parameters:
        granularity - Granularity with which to calculate the sum.
        Returns:
        The Reimann-sum area of the polygon with that granularity.

      • hasVertex

        public boolean hasVertex​(Point point)
        Indicates whether the given point is a vertex of the polygon.
        Parameters:
        point - A point.
        Returns:
        Whether the point is a vertex of the polygon.

      • sharedPoints

        public java.util.List<Point> sharedPoints​(Polygon other)
        Gives a list of vertices that this polygon has in common with some other polygon. It does not calculate intersections between the two polygons.
        Parameters:
        other - Another polygon.
        Returns:
        The vertices in common between this polygon and the other.

      • combine

        public Polygon combine​(Polygon other)
        Merge two polygons. They must be adjacent (as though through split), sharing exactly one side.
        Parameters:
        other - Some other polygon.
        Returns:
        A polygon representing these two polygons combined over one side.

      • base

        public Line base()
        Gives the base of the polygon. A polygon's base is the side on which it lays for minimum vertical height; the line perpendicular to that (running through its peak) is its girth. The best way to traverse a convex polygon with a tool is in the direction of its base to minimize turns.
        Returns:
        The base of the polygon.

      • peak

        public Point peak()
        Gives the peak of the polygon. A polygon's peak is its highest point when laying on its base. Its girth is the line running through the peak perpendicular to the base.
        Returns:
        The base of the polygon.

      • girth

        public Line girth()
        Gives the girth of the polygon. It is the line running through its peak perpendicular to its base. It's also the shortest possible height of the polygon.
        Returns:
        The girth of the polygon.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Renders the polygon as a string.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        The polygon rendered as a string.

      • isProper

        public boolean isProper()
        Gives whether the polygon is proper. A proper polygon has no sides which intersect and is oriented such that its inside faces in. Most functions here behave erratically with improper polygons.
        Returns:
        Whether this polygon is proper.

      • isSimplyTraversable

        public boolean isSimplyTraversable()
        Gives whether this polygon is "simply traversable." A simply traversable polygon is never concave in the direction of its base. A simply traversable polygon can be as efficiently covered as a convex polygon, even if it has some concavities.
        Returns:
        Whether this polygon is simply traversable.

      • verticesBetween

        public java.util.List<Point> verticesBetween​(int v1,
                                             int v2)

      • verticesBetween

        public java.util.List<Point> verticesBetween​(Point v1,
                                             Point v2)
